47.00.text: and contributed over 200 hours of television.

55.52.text: who ruled the country from 1485 to 1603.

59.80.text: A turbulent period that changed the face of British history forever.

- Oh, yeah, no offence!

2817.60.text: No, I'm not going to sulk at all.

2819.24.text: I do have questions to ask you, so stay here.

2821.60.text: What is that our team's tasting?

2823.48.text: You're eating a blancmange of fish.

2830.84.text: One of those things - when we say "blancmange"

2833.04.text: you're instantly taken back to the pink milk jelly of schooldays.

2836.32.text: But blancmange is just white food - "blanc manger".

2839.44.text:
- Of course. 
- Why was white food particularly attractive?

2843.68.text: It's considered to be easier to digest.

2846.04.text: And what have you put into it, in terms of flavourings,

2848.44.text:
- aside from the fish? 
- It's rice boiled until it bursts,

2851.80.text: and then mixed with almond milk,

2855.24.text: er, mashed fish, and flavoured with

2857.36.text: a little bit of sugar and some ginger.

2859.60.text: I can taste the ginger, yeah.

2861.28.text:
- And do you like it, or...? 
- It needs a microwave, but...

2867.64.text: Keeping the dish in mind, then,

2869.56.text: what food-related law - this is your question, for one point -

2877.20.text:
- Oh, well...you had to serve fish on a... 
- Well, not just on a Friday,

2881.04.text: there were certain days you had to eat fish.

2883.32.text: It was Friday plus another day, wasn't it?

2885.84.text: Cos then more fishermen, more trained seamen for the fleet,

2889.40.text: that could be called up, mobilised in times of war.

2891.60.text: You're absolutely right, and it was introduced on Wednesdays

2894.60.text: as well as Fridays and Saturdays.

2897.04.text: And in order to sort of...not circumvent it, but honour the law,

2900.04.text: what other things were included under the guise of "fish"

2903.56.text: that they were allowed to eat?

2905.48.text: Well, you know in the Middle Ages

2906.88.text: they thought that barnacle geese were a type of fish

2911.52.text:
- Yes. And this was included, you're right, barnacle goose. 
- Yeah.

2914.84.text:
- And also puffins. 
- Beaver. 
- And beavers, yes, you're quite right.

2921.00.text: Now, Mark has made a special drink. The cups are almost full.

2924.00.text: Jonathan, your cup is still to be filled.

2926.64.text: And you have prepared something called what for us?

2932.16.text: White hippocras. And what's that made up from?

2936.52.text: ..a Rhenish wine, with long pepper, grains of paradise,

2941.64.text: er, flour of canel, ginger, sugar, and cinnamon.

2948.68.text: You're supposed to be impartial! You weren't eating the food, but...

2951.64.text: I can always drink a drink - I'm a Scotswoman, after all!

2956.24.text: I'm going to ask you, Mark,

2958.48.text: this very beautiful thing, which I almost don't...

2961.40.text: I mean, it's so delicate and gorgeous I almost don't want to touch it.

2964.88.text: It looks like we should have some cherries on it,

2967.20.text: but in fact this would have been used as a drinking vessel?

2971.56.text: Can you fill it up? And I'm going to ask Dan, because I don't want you

2974.40.text: to mess up your beautiful shirt, but I don't mind if Dan messes up his.

2977.36.text: This is where I throw it over everybody, isn't it?

2979.48.text: So this would have been used to drink from. And Dan, do be careful,

2982.72.text: but I want you to have a go at drinking from this.

2985.48.text:
- This tatser, as you said it was called. 
- OK.

2987.40.text: Now, it does look as if it was made from very fine and ancient porcelain.

2992.56.text:
- Yeah. 
- Mark, you tell me what it's made of,

2995.16.text:
- tell everybody. It's extraordinary. 
- That one's actually made from sugar.

2998.44.text:
- What?! 
- Careful you don't tip it!

3000.96.text: But yeah, that's actually made from sugar.

3003.00.text: Are you going to...? Can we break some off?

3009.08.text: Christmas in the Snow household will never be the same.

3011.92.text: Drink and eat at the same time!

3013.28.text: It's like an archaeological object now, isn't it?

3015.48.text: I imagine made with moulds, but terrifically difficult to make.

3018.48.text:
- Yes. 
- Oh, thanks! He's just proved how hard it is to drink out of.

3023.28.text:
- Did he spill it? 
- All over me.

3027.48.text: What's this one made out of?

3031.48.text: I have to say to you, it has been

3032.84.text: fascinating, delightful and intriguing. Thank you very much

3035.72.text: for bringing all this historical food and drink along.

3044.04.text: Now, as our final part of our Tudor feast,

3047.68.text: I want to introduce you to a very special guest.

3052.04.text: And here he is. This is Whiskey.

3055.20.text: Now, Whiskey, for a bonus question, can you tell me

3058.92.text: what this little animal would have been used for in a Tudor kitchen?

3063.68.text:
- Can I answer? 
- You can answer.

3065.12.text: We don't have buzzers, but you can certainly answer.

3069.72.text: Whiskey is supposed to be the last surviving spit dog,

3074.04.text: which is a kind of dog that was bred

3077.04.text: to have a long body and short little legs,

3079.56.text: so it would run about in a little wheel

3081.36.text: and it would stop you having to turn the spit manually.

3085.16.text: You're absolutely right, turn the spit with the meat on it.

3087.80.text: He's the Turnspit Dog. Well done.

3094.96.text: There is nothing about Whiskey, the little Turnspit Dog,

3099.96.text: You already have secured your point, but can you, or can anybody,

3103.56.text: tell me what might have been done -

3105.76.text: of really unspeakable cruelty, I have to say -

3108.48.text: to make little Whiskey run faster on his wheel?

3111.28.text: Did it involve the enema pipe?

3113.20.text: It didn't involve the enema pipe!

3115.52.text: Was there fire put under the wheel, to make him run?

3118.12.text: Yeah, they would throw coals onto the wheel to make him run faster,

3121.20.text: because his little paws were hot.

3123.96.text: Turnspit dogs apparently were used as feet-warmers in church on a Sunday.

3130.80.text: Well, thank you all for being so very game.

3133.16.text: After that round we can reveal that Lucy's team have 20 points

3145.56.text: Now it's time to play our final round.

3156.96.text: So finally, having spent a while looking at how the Tudors lived,

3160.32.text: it seems entirely appropriate that our last round

3165.08.text: This is a quickfire round, with questions worth a point.

3168.32.text: Equally, teams, I should tell you that an incorrect answer

3171.48.text: will result in you being deducted a point.

3174.16.text: Greg looks really happy at that.

3178.56.text: and let's play The Last Word.

3181.60.text: Which monarch said, "When I am dead and opened,

3187.68.text: That's right. "You shall find Calais lying on my heart."

3190.28.text: One point to you. Which Elizabethan playwright was stabbed to death

3193.36.text: in a pub in Deptford... BELL

3197.56.text: It was Christopher Marlowe, it was in a row over a bill.

3200.64.text: Who said that he believed the mercy of Christ

3204.92.text: "yea, though they were greater than can be," on his deathbed?

3209.40.text: I'll move on - that was Henry VIII.

3213.00.text: which Elizabethan statesman died from pneumonia

3218.28.text:
- Francis Bacon. 
- It was Francis Bacon. What was the experiment?

3221.20.text: He was stuffing a chicken with snow.

3223.08.text: He WAS stuffing a chicken with snow!

3224.88.text: Whose death was described as "mildly, like a lamb,

3230.52.text:
- Elizabeth I. 
- That's right. It was mild like a lamb,

3233.72.text: "easily, like a ripe apple from the tree."

3236.40.text: Whose body and severed head was placed in an old arrow chest

3243.96.text:
- That would be Anne Boleyn. 
- It was Anne Boleyn.

3246.24.text: "Most gracious prince, I cry for mercy, mercy, mercy."

3249.36.text:
- It's not working! It is. 
- BELL

3254.92.text: Written to Henry VIII, was the end of that question.

3258.48.text: Whose wife, named Elizabeth, is said to have carried his severed head

3266.16.text: Carried his severed head in a bag for 29 years.

3270.00.text: at the funeral of Henry's widow Catherine Parr?

3274.84.text:
- Was it Elizabeth? 
- No, it wasn't.

3276.32.text:
- It was Lady Jane Grey, you lose a point. 
- Sorry.

3278.60.text: For which monarch were two funeral services held,

3285.00.text:
- Edward VI. 
- It was Edward VI. Next question. How was Richard Roose,

3288.48.text: the cook of the Bishop of Rochester, executed?

3293.40.text: He was boiled alive for two hours, apparently.

3299.80.text: Well, that sound signals the end of the round

3302.76.text: and indeed, the end of the quiz.

3305.80.text: I can tell you that Lucy's team have 25 points

3321.04.text: So Dan's team get the silver Tudor groats,

3323.12.text: and I'm afraid that Lucy's team, it's off to the Tower for you,

3328.80.text: The only thing left to do, then,

3330.80.text: is to pay one last visit to our Tudor timeline.

3333.72.text: Here it is. Full of the people and events that have made this

3338.20.text: one of the most remarkable periods in British history.

3353.52.text: Thank you to our wonderful historians, Lucy, Greg and Kate,

3361.72.text: I'd like to thank all of you for watching,

3364.28.text: and in the words of that great Elizabethan, William Shakespeare,

3372.40.text: and then put out the light. Goodnight.
